p:
In addition to high affinity rG binding, env1 also recognizes more structurally divergent 2′-dG derivatives. Compared to M. florum 2′-dG-I, env1 is more tolerant toward chemically related compounds as demonstrated by its higher binding affinities and weaker discrimination against the antiviral drugs acyclovir and pencyclovir. Env1 binds acyclovir and pencyclovir more tightly ( K D = 560 ± 10 nM and 2.0 ± 0.1 μM, respectively) than M. florum ( K D = 4.8 ± 1.3 and 22 ± 1.1 μM, respectively), and displays a lowered ability to discriminate between the antiviral and 2′-dG ( K rel,
env1
(lig/2′-dG) = 16 for acyclovir and 59 for pencyclovir; K rel,
M. florum
(lig/2′-dG) = 28 for acyclovir and 132 for pencyclovir). Thus, while the env1 riboswitch achieves higher affinity binding for 2′-dG than other riboswitches, it appears that its ability to discriminate between closely related metabolites and RNA-binding drugs is significantly diminished—a noteworthy example that higher affinity binding does not necessarily correlate with higher specificity.
